articles.title: The State of JavaScript 2024 Results
articles.description: We recently encouraged you to take the annual State of JavaScript survey; the results are now out. 14,015 folks took part and we get to see what language features folks are using, experiences with popular libraries, build tool popularity, AI preferences, popular podcasts, runtime usage, and perhaps controversially, how more JavaScript developers are using TypeScript than not. There‚Äôs a lot to dig through here.
articles.author: Sacha Greif

articles.title: 1.¬†console.delight
articles.description: By far our most popular link of the year with over 20,000 clicks(!) ‚Äì but who doesn't use and love console.log? This post showed us how in the browser console it's not merely for printing plain text, but can be used to render things like SVGs and HTML.
articles.author: Zach Saucier

articles.title: 2.¬†JavaScript Visualized: Promise Execution
articles.description: A well-diagrammed article coupled with an (optional) 8 minute video that went into how promises work under the hood. Hugely popular as most of Lydia's content tends to be.
articles.author: Lydia Hallie

articles.title: 3.¬†Is htmx Just Another JavaScript Framework?
articles.description: Despite being five years old, htmx has seen a surge in popularity in 2023 and 2024, partly due to framework fatigue, but also as its simple HTML-oriented approach to adding functionality to pages appeals to a diverse group of developers. v2.0 landed in June.
articles.author: Alexander Petros

articles.title: 4.¬†Ecma International Approves ECMAScript 2024: What‚Äôs New?
articles.description: In June, the Ecma General Assembly approved the latest ECMAScript / JavaScript spec, officially making it a standard. As with ES2023, it was a reasonably small step forward, but Dr. Axel rounded up what was new.
articles.author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

articles.title: 5.¬†JavaScript's ??= Operator: Default Values Made Simple
articles.description: The ??= nullish coalescing assignment operator snuck into JavaScript a few years ago via ES2021 and has been broadly supported almost everywhere for ages. Trevor showed off how it can tighten up your assignments.
articles.author: Trevor I. Lasn

articles.title: 6.¬†Eloquent JavaScript: The Fourth Edition
articles.description: Coming several years after the third edition, the latest version of what is, perhaps, the best ‚Äòall rounder‚Äô book for learning JavaScript arrived in March ‚Äúadjusted to the realities of 2024 and generally touched up.‚Äù
articles.author: Marijn Haverbeke

articles.title: 7.¬†33 JavaScript Concepts Every Developer Should Know
articles.description: A curated collection of links to tutorials on 33 different areas it‚Äôs worth understanding well, including types, closures, equality, scope, and different engines.
articles.author: Leonardo Maldonado

articles.title: 8.¬†How Google Handles JavaScript In Its Indexing Process
articles.description: At one point if you wanted Google to index your content it needed to be directly written in HTML and not dynamically rendered with JavaScript. Things have since changed, of course, but by how much?
articles.author: Zecchini, Moore, Siddle, Ubl (Vercel)

articles.title: 01:¬†Twelve Modern CSS One-Line Upgrades
articles.description: Stephanie shared this list of a dozen CSS properties that are well worth knowing earlier in the year ‚Äî the one-line upgrades here will help reduce technical debt, remove unnecessary lines of JavaScript, and score some easy wins for the user experience, too.
articles.author: Stephanie Eckles

articles.title: 02:¬†Five CSS Snippets Every Frontend Developer Should Know in 2024
articles.description: Adam did this in 2023, and the 2024 version proved very popular too. All the snippets here are toolbelt worthy, powerful, CSS tips (including nesting, sub grid, container query units, etc) that will be just as valuable as we head into 2025.
articles.author: Adam Argyle

articles.title: 03:¬†Inline Conditionals in CSS?
articles.description: In the summer the CSS Working Group resolved to add an inline if() to CSS. An exciting step for CSS, but one that raises lots of questions too. This explainer from Lea proved valuable for many.
articles.author: Lea Verou

articles.title: 04:¬†What You Need to Know about Modern CSS
articles.description: A bookmarkable guide from this past Spring featuring a list of all the then new additions to CSS (think nesting, view transitions, :has(), etc). It remains really handy, as there‚Äôs an explainer, demo, code example, and a quick bit of detail as to why you should care about each entry. If you want to scrub up on what new CSS features we've gotten this year, this ain't a bad place to look.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: 05:¬†How to Center a Div
articles.description: The fact that so many of you tapped on this one tells us that it's still something of a tricky ordeal to get right. Yes, it's easier now thanks to new tools (Flex, Grid, etc), but which to use? Josh shares the trade-offs between different approaches, and the best strategies to use.
articles.author: Josh W Comeau

articles.title: 06:¬†The Magic of Clip Path
articles.description: This post sets out to ‚Äúinspire you and show you that thinking outside the box can lead to some great animations‚Äù ‚Äî all via the magic of the very powerful clip-path CSS property.
articles.author: Emil Kowalski

articles.title: 07:¬†CSS Selectors
articles.description: A thorough, complete guide covering all of the various methods we have to select elements in CSS (such as pseudo-selectors, nested selectors, attribute selectors, etc) and how to use them for applying styles.
articles.author: Geoff Graham

articles.title: 08:¬†An Interactive Guide to CSS Container Queries
articles.description: This is a detailed explainer on CSS container queries, exploring the problems they solve, how they work, and how we can use them in our workflows. Lots of code and visuals to help things along too. Well worth bookmarking.
articles.author: Ahmad Shadeed

articles.title: 09:¬†How to Make Your Web Page Faster Before It Even Loads
articles.description: Salma looked at the events that happen before the first byte of a web page is even received by the browser. Asking if we can measure those events, and subsequently optimize them to make our web pages and applications load even faster. Neat.
articles.author: Salma Alam-Naylor

articles.title: 10:¬†The Frontend Developer/Engineer Handbook 2024
articles.description: This incredibly in-depth and detailed guide on the current web development landscape was well received. It's remains a superb resource for getting up to speed on everything from code editors, CSS, UX, UI, the command line, performance, accessibility, testing, AI, and much, much more.
articles.author: Cody Lindley

articles.title: Anchor Position Tool
articles.description: CSS anchor positioning is on the way, and one rather neat layout mechanism that‚Äôs part of the spec is position-area. This (Chromium 129+ only) demo from Una demonstrates how it works. There was plenty of interest in this one, and although it's still in draft, it should prove rather powerful once widely available.
articles.author: Una Kravets

articles.title: Speedometer 3.0: A Browser Benchmark for Webapp Responsiveness
articles.description: 2024 gave us a new major release of Speedometer ‚Äî the first with a cross-industry collaborative approach supported by each major browser engine (Blink, Gecko, WebKit). Version 3 added in many new tests, performance wins, and improvements. You can run the test for yourself here.
articles.author: Apple, Google, Microsoft, and Mozilla

articles.title: CSS Grid Generator
articles.description: This handy browser-based tool got plenty of you clicking ‚Äî you can use it to easily create custom CSS grid layouts ‚Äî you can specify the number of columns, rows, and gutter size.
articles.author: Kristjan Retter
